text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide a right to privacy and self-determination. The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives. According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections of the Bill of Rights. For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom of association, the Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering of soldiers in peacetime, the Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home against unreasonable search and seizure, the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination, and the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified rights of the people. It's both fortunate and unfortunate those rights have not been specified. Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities, such as racial and ethnic groups need special protection under the Constitution, particularly to ensure that they have equal access to this nation's political and governmental processes. So, with all these protections, why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without discrimination? The answer is not because of any lack of cases. The Court ducked a number of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggle out of one Virginia case in 1976 by affirming a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons. In short, the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away. Why? Well, because with all of these other holdings setting the trend, the court would appear extremely inconsistent if it decided against gay rights. And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights, despite negative public opinion, the court might undermine its authority and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings. After all, the United States Supreme Court has no army to back up its decisions, nor does it have control of federal funds with which to coerce compliance. Another possible reason for the court's reluctance to handle gay rights cases is that the court's two liberal members, Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan, fear they would be outvoted on the issue. And they've been delaying gay rights cases because they fear a bad decision would be worse than no decision. If Brennan and Marshall are stalling for a time when the court would be more liberal, it is doubtful they will live long enough. Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health. And if Reagan is reelected, we probably will have an extremely conservative Supreme Court for the rest of this century. So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates, to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year, and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights, for better or for worse. National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco, is a private, non-profit law firm that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation. It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it finds lawyers nationwide who are willing to donate their time to specific cases. As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal efforts. They're all yours. Thank you. Thank you very much. I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you about the current gay rights litigation that's going on around the country. And what I'd like to do is sort of break it down by different categories. And rather than lecture, I'd just assume make it more of a discussion. So if you have questions as I'm going along, feel free to raise your hands and interrupt. I understand that a good number of you are not law students and so I'll try to keep my terms as general and in the lay language as possible. If you don't understand something I'm talking about, Please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can. I'd like to start out first talking about an area which is very important to gay rights advocates. It's an issue we've been working on for about five years and that's the immigration naturalization issue. And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue which I think many of you will find important, which is the rights of gay students in this country. And by no means is this issue settled at all. In the area of immigration naturalization, we won Gay Rights Advocates a very important victory in the U.S. District Court in the Northern District of California in the case of Carl Hill versus INS. And the Immigration Nationality Act prohibits homosexuals from entering the country. However, you don't find the word homosexual anywhere in that act. What you find is the Supreme Court decision, which has interpreted the language of the act to exclude homosexuals and the precise terminology that they interpreted was psychopathic personality. Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic personality, they must be excluded from the country. Now the question is, which we raised in the Carl Hill case, how do you determine who is a homosexual? It is our position in gay rights advocates that the only way to make this determination under the law is through an examination by a public health service doctor. That doctor must examine the arriving alien and say to that alien to our gay issue, what is known as a Class A certificate, and then the INS can exclude the person from the country. Now, the government's position is that a person is able to decide for themselves whether or not they're gay. And if they say they're gay, They are gay and can be excluded from the country. This is the issue. The U.S. District Court here at the Northern District of California agreed with pay rights advocates that a doctor's certificate from the Public Health Service must issue. The case involved Carl Hill who is a tourist who is here for pleasure and a journalist, a photographer for a London newspaper, a London newspaper. Now the same issue rose again in the case of Richard Longstaff which is a case that we have just filed a petition for review in the United States Supreme Court, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision. The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans. Mr. Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas. He's been here about 20 years now. He came here on a valid immigrant visa. He subsequently opened up two boutiques, clothing stores, and hairdressing salons. He employs about 20 citizens of this country. He pays over $100,000 a year in income taxes. And our government has said to Richard Longstaff, you're not good enough to be an American citizen. Why has our government said that? Because Richard Longstaff is gay. And that is the position that the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld. So what we have now is a clear conflict between two circuits. I might have skipped over to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals here has affirmed the decision of Carl Hill. What we did is file a petition to the Supreme Court asking them to review the Fifth Circuit decision and to resolve the conflict between the two different courts and appeals. We feel that there's a good chance that the Supreme Court will agree to hear the case, and part of the reason is that there's no constitutional issues. We're not asking this court, this very conservative Supreme Court, to create any new constitutional issues of rights for gay people. All we're asking them to do is resolve what is essentially an interagency dispute, and it's more of a question of statutory construction. So our petition was filed in that case at the end of January. The government's brief is due on Friday, and the new case clerk at the Supreme Court tells me that the Supreme Court will probably make a decision in three to four weeks after that. So we could be seeing a decision in that soon. Now here in the Ninth Circuit, the government filed a petition for what's known as a rehearing on the bond, meaning that they wanted the entire court of appeals for the Ninth Circuit to review that decision. And the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition. That came down January 17th. So what we'll find, too, is that the government will undoubtedly be asking the Supreme Court to also review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I think, to ask for that review is because as a result of our victory at the lower court level, we filed a petition for attorneys' fees in the amount of $340,000. So there's a little incentive for the government to appeal the case. In addition, on the congressional level, there's been some legislation that is going to be introduced by Barney Frank from Massachusetts and we helped him draft that legislation which would change the exclusions so that it would eliminate the sexual deviants and psychopathic personality exclusions of gay people from the country. The next area I want to talk to you about is the military. The military has an absolute policy that gay people cannot serve, and the only exception to this policy is not really for the status of being gay, but someone who commits a homosexual sexual act. If they renounce that act, they say, oh, Christ, was I drunk last night, I didn't know what I was doing, you know, it was a mistake, it's never going to happen again, please let me stay in the military, they can stay in. Other than that, everybody else is out. Now, the progress we've made in the last few years, at least at the discharge, will be on your honorable conditions and will be entitled to full benefits. However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career of the service, this can still be pretty severe after you've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits in your particular chosen career and to have the government, in fact, say to you, well, you're not good enough to fight and die for your country either. We have a test case pending in the Washington, D.C. circuit, in court of appeals now, involved a man who was originally stationed out here at Monterey, the Language Institute. That's Jim Dronenberg. He's a specialist in Korean cryptology. He had been in the service for nine years. Three months before his discharge, he had been given a $12,000 relistment bonus. He had had accommodation after accommodation after accommodation. They thought he was an excellent soldier, until they found out who was gay, they picked him out. The strategy of bringing the case in the District of Columbia was that by reputation, the District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals is the most liberal in the country. And in addition, the issue had been decided here in the Ninth Circuit some years ago by a case that we had brought in Lawson, that's known as Beller versus Lindor. So there was no avenue available for redress here. And the strategy also would be that if we were able to get into the D.C. court, then that would resolve the issue for all soldiers because the issue of jurisdiction and venue revolved around where was the defendant located. It was our position that the Department of Defense and the headquarters of the Department of Navy were located in Washington, D.C. And the government fought us tooth and nail on this. In fact, two-thirds of their brief they argued that the court didn't have jurisdiction, and essentially for the merits of the case, all they did was say, well, another court out there in San Francisco decided this issue, and so it's what Anthony Bump said. Well, we won half that case. We won the jurisdiction issue. We lost on the merits. Now we're in the court of appeals, and our strategy, we found, backfired on us, because the odds maybe were a thousand to one of drawing three conservative judges in which room, three of the most conservative judges you could ever want to have. One of them started asking questions about did the right to privacy include the right to have sex with animals? And you have to start off at this level, you can't be too optimistic about the result. One of the other judges who was a Reagan appointee to the bench was a former professor of law at the University of Chicago Law School and a student who did work for Gay Rights Advocates because a volunteer last summer had this judge as a professor for constitutional law, and when this man came to the issue of abortion rights, he said, I'm Catholic, and I have nine children, and that's enough said about abortion, let's move on. So, as you can see, we're not too optimistic about that case. There was a really great brief filed by the American Civil Liberties Union in that unique as crowd group or friend of the court group. And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale that the military uses for excluding gays and they compared it to the same rationale that the military used to segregate blacks from the service to say, look, white men are never gonna sleep in the same barracks as black men. White soldiers are never gonna sleep with blacks. So how can a black maintain control and command respect? And this is the same kind of thing they say about gays and lesbians in the service, that it just isn't going to work out. And what they're doing is trying to institutionalize society's prejudice rather than trying to deal with underlying problems. So it's a very good, very detailed, brief and very enlightening book that takes some note of it. The paradox to what's going on in the military is that if you're a civilian employee of the military, there's almost, it's almost impossible to get rid of you. of you, regardless of what kind of activity you're involved in. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has recently found that a person who is a convicted child molester still could not be discharged from the Navy, absent a showing that there was some connection with his job duties in the Navy, what we call the nexus between his activity and his job requirements. And another area that we find to promise that people who want to make a career out of the military, they make every effort to get rid of them as soon as they can. And those who want to get out, somebody who covers after they're in the service that they realize that their sexual orientation does not mean what they thought it was and they come to the commanding officer and they say, I'm gay, these people flounder around in the system often for a year or more before they discharge, even though the regulations are And how we resolve that problem, I can't really say, but it really is sort of a schizophrenic kind of attitude, that they just can't make up their mind what they want. Other problems that we found now, too, is that the military, in some instances, are trying to prosecute soldiers for asking for a discharge, saying that they enlisted frauds fraudulent. They knew at the time that they enlisted that they were gay, that their enlistment therefore was fraudulent and they were trying to have them prosecuted. There's a case up on appeal on the 10th Circuit Court in Denver, and it's been there for some time, so you shouldn't see a decision pretty soon in that case. Another thing that we find the military is doing now is suing people who've gone through ROTC, and apparently they have some kind of or they subsidized your educational benefits. And the case that came before us last year, there was a person who went through medical school, of course, in the U.S. Army. And then when he finished, said, I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint not because I realize I'm gay. So the Army said, well, I think we're gonna have to sue you for $60,000 to reimburse us for the cost of your education. We were willing to defend this man, but he didn't have the desire to go through several years of litigation. It takes a lot of effort to go through that. And what he did instead was find more bankers. But in any case, the military picked up the bill. Or for those of you who are working, I guess we all picked up the bill in a sense. Which leads me to the next thing that we've done is based on some data we've collected over the last couple of years, we can make a pretty good estimate that the cost of separating gay people from the military is at least $20 million a year. That on average the military separates about 1,800 soldiers a year from the service because of homosexuality. And that based on a recent RAND Corporation study, cost of training a soldier through basic training The first 22 weeks is $100,000. So simple arithmetic will show that that's $18 billion. And my experience is most of the people that are being discharged have been around for a lot more than 22 weeks. What's the situation with the conscription where somebody turns 19 and is supposed to go to the post office, says, I'm gay, how does the system deal with that? Well, you probably wouldn't necessarily tell the postmaster, but you would still have to register. And it wouldn't really become an issue until we were called up. And at that time, what happens is that you're given a questionnaire and asked you to list all of your childhood diseases and broken bones, and there's a square somewhere that says how you fit in with homosexual tendencies. What happens then, though? If you check the box and say you are so afflicted, then you will be deferred. You will not be taken, conducted, in the military. you cannot be inducted into the military. If you do not check the box, you could be inducted. However, if you know that you're gay and you don't check that box, you are subject to penalties of as much as five years in prison and $5,000, if they could subsequently prove the case against you. Let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit. Something that's been in the news just recently was AB1 finally passed both houses and sitting on Duke's desk waiting for signature. What most people don't know in this state is that all that bill does is codify a Supreme court decision which already extends sexual orientation, discrimination, protection to all employers in the state. The only thing is that not all employees are covered. And this was the case of gay law students versus specific telephone and telegraph. And I say it doesn't cover all employees because it only covers those employees who are open or out on the job. Their employers got to know that they're gay. Because part of what the Supreme Court of California said in that case was that being out on the job is political activity. And that in this state, an employer may not discriminate against an employee based on political activity. Political activity is much broader than partisan politics. It goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties, includes political causes. Women's rights, labor union rights, K-Rights. So what the AV-1 does is protect those people who are not out on their job and it also gives them an administrative remedy by going through the Fair Employment and Housing Administration rather than having to file a suit directly in court. Other employment work that we're doing at K-Rights Advocates, one involves against an act named the Helms Bill in Oklahoma. The Helms Bill is essentially similar to the Bridge Initiative that was up here in California a few years back. While the Bridge Initiative was defeated here in California, it's lost in Oklahoma. And we filed a suit challenging that bill, and we lost district court level in Oklahoma. We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver. We had oral arguments last September, so we're looking for a decision any time in that case. The Helms bill, we call, the main issue was First Amendment freedom of expression. That was the main cause of action. It was also we raised due process and equal protection arguments as well as right to privacy. In this kind of litigation, I'll tell you, for some of you who are law students and don't realize, and the rest of you do not. We're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat of our pants. I mean, this is new. And when we're in the courts, we're making new law. The gay rights litigation that's going on in this country has essentially taken place in the last 10 to 15 years. 10 years ago, GRA didn't exist. And there were no gay legal organizations around the country. And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the courts. and it's not uncommon to find all sorts of oppressive legislation in the books. So we don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents. We have to analogize a lot to the struggles that were won in the women's movement, and to the black movement, and other First Amendment types of cases, the privacy decisions that came out of the abortion litigation and the contraceptive litigation. That's where we sort of draw. Sometimes we make apologies, sometimes we just make up theories. You have to go in there. So we feel, at Gay Rights Advocates, we have a very aggressive litigation posture. If we don't go into court and file suit, then we've lost before we've even started. There is, in a sense, nothing to lose by going into court. Because in the case of the Helmsville situation, the bill's on the books. And if we lose, the bill's still on the books. So what did we lose? But at least we go in there and fight, we have a chance of winning. And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits. There's educational benefits. There's consciousness raising. There's all the press we've got. In general, there's a lot of good press. People just cannot believe the situations I've been ascribing to you tonight about the military and immigration, these kind of things happening in America today in 1984. It's just incredible. And so we feel there's a certain value to bringing lawsuits, win orders. And it's making a statement, generally, too, that, you know, you've pushed this community around for just so long, and now we're, you know, it's your game, but we can play it, too. And we're going to be there, and we're going to fight, and we're going to win. You know, maybe we're not going to win all the time, but you're not going to knock us out of the ring, because you're going to be right back there fighting every time. That's what getting rights to advocates is all about. I didn't really follow what you're arguing about regarding saying you rest your personal time. I assume that you cannot be ganged with a teacher. Well, actually, the law is so broad that it could exclude straight people as well because the language prohibits homosexual activity and homosexual conduct, neither of which is defined as engaging in what we would call homosexual sexual conduct. It's mere mention, mere discussing of homosexual rights subject to teacher to a disciplinary hearing of impossible discharge from their employment. But the terms in the law are so vague and so general that it's hard to tell exactly what could be brought within the purview of the law. But essentially, it's expressions. It's talking about and discussing anything about Homestead Trial. What was the name of the case of gay law students versus Pacific telephone attorney? In regard to that case and AB1, it sounded, what I heard was that dismissing employees on those grounds is prohibited. Wouldn't AB1 also apply to job applicants and to promotion processes? And it does specific telephone telegrams. It does. All types of employment related discrimination. Promotions, fringe benefits, the hiring process, the whole lot of those. I haven't taken a look at it in a while, but that's a whole other issue, and I think that's sort of the issue of the 80s, is the rights of gay couples. We're going to be doing some gay couple litigation. We did one case already, and we have two pending now, which I'll go into a little bit. One that we're going to do in Columbia, Maryland, which involves the American Automobile Association and their motor club. They offer a discount to married couples, but not to a gay couple, a lesbian couple. and we're demanding that they extend that same benefit to gay couples. The case arose in Columbia, Maryland, which is situated in Howard County. Howard County has a very broad anti-discrimination ordinance that prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation, as well as marital status. It really is a sort of a marital status type discrimination as opposed to sexual orientation. However, gay people cannot be legally married anywhere in the country. And so it necessarily impacts on the gay community very heavily. So that's in the administrative process now. And I think whoever loses that's probably going to appeal. So we're looking toward a long court battle out there. We have another case that's in a sort of free adversary position right now down in southern California in La Jolla, where there's a gay couple that's been living together for six years. They have a relationship contract that governs their relationship, and they also are heading to dispute the AAA, this time with the automobile insurance, and AAA offers apparently a 20% spousal discount, but this couple of course cannot qualify for that spousal discount. So we just might have to sue AAA on that issue as well. There are a number of areas where gay people, because they cannot be lawfully married, have fewer benefits and employment fringe benefits and taxation and so on, pension plans. And we don't necessarily, as I said earlier, expect to win all these cases, especially in the beginning. This is, we're looking at at least a 10-year program. But we're going to start raising the consciousness of the insurance industry. There are already at least two insurance carriers that I'm aware of that offer what they call domestic partnership or adult living companion that have different euphemisms. But they offer the plan already. And I think essentially these discounts are marketing gimmicks. I don't think there's any sound insurance reasons why they offer them. And so it's just going to be a matter of breaking it down. new insurance carriers start offering the program and they find out that it's profitable, I think we'll find many more start offering it as well. Some other employment cases we're involved in, one involves a high school guidance counselor in Mad River, Ohio. Marjorie Rowland came out on her job and she didn't have her contract renewed because of her sexual orientation. She won the district court level, won an order for reinstatement and a $40,000 judgment for lost wages, and the school district appealed the case to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati. We had oral arguments in that case last June, so I think we'll be seeing a decision on that one pretty soon now, too. In Minnesota, there's a judge there by the name of Robert Crane Winton, who's been on the bench for about, excuse me, 19 years. And according to all his peers, he's a very able and competent judge, but he's being recommended for removal because he would not take a vow of celibacy. Crane Ritten is gay. His sexual orientation came to light when he was arrested and charged with solicitation for prostitution, which he subsequently entered a plea to two misdemeanors. soliciting male prostitutes. Now, what makes the case an interesting one of discrimination is that two years earlier, a straight judge in Minnesota was arrested and fled out to the same charges with female prostitutes. He was given a reprimand and a $250 fine. Crane Winton has been ordered to pay a $46,000 fine and recommended for removal from the bench. and the straight judge was not asked to take a vial of celibacy. Now, the vial of celibacy comes from the fact that Minnesota has a sodomy statute on the coast. Most people think that sodomy statutes prohibit gay people from having sex. Well, what most people don't understand is that that same statute in virtually every state that has a sodomy statute prohibits all sexual activity other than between a husband and life in a missionary position. So even straight people are subject to the same law. In most states, it's a felony. And I'm telling you, these laws are enforced. In Nevada, a man was recently given 22 consecutive life terms for committing the abominable crime against nature. And in that case involved a teenager. And so you can say, well, okay, this is minors, it's not the same. I can assure you a straight man would have never received the same sentence In addition, another case I'm just aware of in Nevada, where there was a scorned lover who called the police because he walked in on his lover having sex with another man, and the police came out and they caught the people, what we say, flagrant delecto, in bed. This man was arrested, he was charged with sodomy, he was given a 20 year sentence, first offense. So, I'll tell you, these laws, they're in effect, They're enforced. And even more than that, there's something that we are attacking around the country because there's a great psychological barrier to obtaining gay rights in this country. It's sort of the bedrock of discrimination. How can we give employment protection to criminals? City councils sit around and debate, extending civil rights orders to protect people on the basis of sexual orientation. How can we give civil rights protection to criminals? So this is the kind of thing that we have to get rid of in these sodomy laws. We have participated recently in a national conference of some other gay organizations and sponsored by the National American Civil Liberties Union in New York last fall where we are going to put together a strategy attacking the remaining 25 sodomy statutes in this country. We're going to go after them one by one and knock them off. We're going to figure out what's the best form. Do we want to be in the state court? Do we want to be in the federal court? What is the correct time? What is the correct mode for attacking this case? Is it going to be in the criminal context? Is it going to be a civil challenge? And we're going to go after these statutes, and we're going to get rid of them. There was a significant victory in the sodomy challenge litigation last year in the case of Baker v. Wade, came out of the U.S. District Court in Dallas, Texas, which ruled that that Sodom Statute of Texas was unconstitutional. The Amarillo District Attorney decided to appeal that decision, even though the State Attorney General did not. That case is now before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit of New Orleans, and oral arguments have been scheduled for the second week in March. That case, I feel quite certain will also be appealed to the Supreme Court, regardless of who wins. Now what happened in that case, it's sort of a new twist, was that at the Court of Appeals level, the district attorney said, we've got to have a sodomy statute on the books because we need it to control AIDS. Well, at the time that that sodomy statute was passed, I assure you nobody had ever even heard of AIDS. And furthermore, the state and the district attorney did not litigate the AIDS issue at the trial level. And so it was our position at the court of appeals level that it's too late, cannot bring up a new issue for the first time at the court of appeals level. That same argument is being made in Sodomy Challenge to the law in Georgia. And there, the case is on appeal before the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. The other case that's pending now that could have some impact, quite considerable impact in fact, on solid litigation in the future is a case which is presently before the U.S. Supreme Court. This is the Uplinger case which came out of the state of New York. A couple of years ago, by way of background, the New York Court of Appeals, which is the the highest court in that state. Struck down the Sodom Statute in New York. They said it was unconstitutional. The state applied for a writ of cert to the US Supreme Court. They asked the US Supreme Court to review the decision. The US Supreme Court refused to grant the writ. So the court action became final. What we still have left on the books was a law which made it illegal to ask somebody to engage in deviant sexual behavior, what they call voidering for the solicitation of deviant sexual behavior, which is defined as sonomy. So when a man named Robert Uplinger was arrested and charged under that statute, the end result in the court was, well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act, why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act? And they struck down the solicitation statute also. This time, the district attorney in Buffalo appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert to the U.S. Supreme Court when the U.S. Supreme Court granted it. And the speculation was that the reason they granted it was that they changed their mind about the Monopoly case and they really wanted to review the underlying issues of the sodomy legislation in New York. And in fact, that was an argument that was made in the petition by the DA. Now, some events happened since that petition was filed. And when the final brief was filed for the state of New York for the district attorney of Buffalo, he did not argue that the Siamese statute needed to be reconsidered. And an interesting twist, too, was that the attorney general of the state of New York, Robert Abrams, filed an amicus brief supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals that the law was unconstitutional. So you had, in effect, the state's attorney general and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue. NGRA filed a amicus brief in the Supreme Court arguing that the petition was improperly granted and that they had just threw the whole thing out without deciding it. And what we're hoping is that they are not going to reach the underlying issues because the one thing they're not properly before the court, it wasn't an issue in the lower court decision. And secondly, they were not adequately briefed because as I said, it was not an issue. Oral arguments have already been presented in that case. We're expecting a decision on the later this spring. And depending on what happens in that case, it could have a significant impact on your litigation for a good number of years to come. Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area of security clearances. Security clearances are necessary for people, many people who work for the government or work for private industry that do contracts with the government, generally the areas of energy and defense. And what security clearance means is that the government says that you are okay to look at classified information and feel that you're not going to divulge this information. There's different levels of security clearance. Gay people over the years had a great deal of problem getting security clearance. And what we found is that the government's policy on this is somewhat inconsistent. They do not have an interagency plan or set of guidelines or criteria. Each agency decides on its own. And there's an awful lot of discretion that What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person can get a security clearance. Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I call them the police agencies, the FBI, the CIA, the National Security Agency, are hanging in there tough and they will not grant security clearance to anybody they know is gay. There's been some recent mitigation against the CIA. There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia District Court. It's before Judge Barrington Parker. And he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment in that case for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles, the U.S. District Court down there, involving John Green, who was an engineer with a company known as TRW. He's worked for TRWF, I believe, for 13 years and he's never had any problems. The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information or divulged any information, but basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay, and therefore might divulge information. So that argument breaks down. The person says, I'm not subject to blackmail, I'm open about my sexuality. My family knows, my friends know, there's no big deal to me, I don't know why it's a big deal to you, to you, but to the CIA it's still a big deal and they can't, they just cannot understand why there might be some kind of, or might not be some kind of problem here. So that case is pending in the U.S. District Court. The government just yesterday filed its brief, they filed a motion to dismiss, they said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the to hear the case based on sovereign immunity. They said the government did not consent to be sued in this case. And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government by getting involved in this matter. They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not. So they will be responsible for you following that on March the 2nd. I'll talk only about two more issues. One is briefly some First Amendment cases that we're involved in is we find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco, we have a Bay Area reporter being censored at a number of prisons around the country. Prisoners that want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not being allowed to read these papers. So we're going to be involved in a suit probably, at the Luther Luckett Congressional Correctional Act Institute in Kentucky, and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison, and possibly one down in Texas as well. And then last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students. Well, I went to several undergraduate schools. I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in the gay political process. And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events. And Michigan State University is on the main thoroughfare. 40,000 cars a day passed through this intersection. We wanted to put a banner that said, Hey Pride Week. And the administration wouldn't let us. So we filed an action against the university. We didn't win, but it's probably because we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from some of our sources post-administration that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year because they probably did some pretty serious trouble. So the next year, we made an application to put up the ban on women and women not to have any problems. Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971, last year they allowed that gay students be kicked out of the fraternity, simply because they were gay. So even though you have an anti-iscrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot, but it's not enforced. So there are continuing problems going on. We found that there's a school in another school mission called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they were gay. There's a private college in Southern Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework and said this person is gay and he doesn't meet the good moral character requirements of our schools and he can't handle this degree. We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has official, granted official university recognition to the student organization there, but they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any of those benefits that might go along with official recognition. There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus. And my last big Bay Rights case before I came to the West Coast involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. because they were not granted recognition to the undergraduate and to the law school gay student organizations. So there are still a lot of lawsuits involved with students, as well as many other areas that are important to them. We can become complacent during California. It doesn't have a Sodom statue anymore. We have a lot of protections. People to a greater extent may be a lot more relaxed. They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community. It's sort of this old hat. But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems. And that's what national gay rights advocates It's all balance. It's fighting these legal battles. I'm not doing this for the country. Is InterRet's app just taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality if they have not been treated as a concern? Because that's simply something in California that is sort of an issue. And it's very complicated. Yeah. There's a lot of problems in that area. We have not taken on any cases involving that issue. I can't say we've been presented with any. What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for the people to come to us, which is not much of a problem. I get calls every day. If they don't go by, they don't get at least one call. So they're concerned about some kind of discrimination or adverse action. But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet. You do talk about this in housing. I just wanted to point out that this city, Denver, has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together, and this is often used against gay couples. It's the status of those in the community that matter. We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem. That is a way of, certainly, of discriminating against gay people without being so forthright as saying, that we're not going to allow two gays to live together. The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure it was necessarily anti-gay, but it was intended to keep noise down and to protect sort of family-type environments. But it certainly had an impact on gay people. In some areas like that, it's very subtle with legislation and impact. In some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.

segments.text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide a right to privacy and self-determination.
The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives.
According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections
of the Bill of Rights.
For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom
of association, the Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering
of soldiers in peacetime, the Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home
against unreasonable search and seizure, the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination,
and the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified
rights of the people. It's both fortunate and unfortunate those rights have not been
specified. Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups
considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities, such as racial and ethnic
groups need special protection under the Constitution, particularly to ensure that they have equal
access to this nation's political and governmental processes. So, with all these protections,
why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without
discrimination? The answer is not because of any lack of cases. The Court ducked a number
of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggle out of one Virginia case in 1976 by affirming
a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons. In short,
the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away. Why? Well, because with
all of these other holdings setting the trend, the court would appear extremely inconsistent
if it decided against gay rights.
And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights,
despite negative public opinion,
the court might undermine its authority
and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings.
After all, the United States Supreme Court
has no army to back up its decisions,
nor does it have control of federal funds
with which to coerce compliance.
Another possible reason for the court's reluctance
to handle gay rights cases
is that the court's two liberal members,
Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan,
fear they would be outvoted on the issue.
And they've been delaying gay rights cases
because they fear a bad decision
would be worse than no decision.
If Brennan and Marshall are stalling
for a time when the court would be more liberal,
it is doubtful they will live long enough.
Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health.
And if Reagan is reelected,
we probably will have an extremely conservative
Supreme Court for the rest of this century.
So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates,
to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year,
and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights, for better or for worse.
National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco, is a private, non-profit law firm
that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation.
It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it finds lawyers nationwide
who are willing to donate their time to specific cases.
As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal
efforts.
They're all yours.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you about the current gay rights litigation
that's going on around the country.
And what I'd like to do is sort of break it
down by different categories.
And rather than lecture, I'd just assume make it more
of a discussion.
So if you have questions as I'm going along,
feel free to raise your hands and interrupt.
I understand that a good number of you are not law students
and so I'll try to keep my terms as general
and in the lay language as possible.
If you don't understand something I'm talking about,
Please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can.
I'd like to start out first talking about an area
which is very important to gay rights advocates.
It's an issue we've been working on for about five years
and that's the immigration naturalization issue.
And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue
which I think many of you will find important,
which is the rights of gay students in this country.
And by no means is this issue settled at all.
In the area of immigration naturalization,
we won Gay Rights Advocates a very important victory
in the U.S. District Court
in the Northern District of California
in the case of Carl Hill versus INS.
And the Immigration Nationality Act
prohibits homosexuals from entering the country.
However, you don't find the word homosexual
anywhere in that act.
What you find is the Supreme Court decision,
which has interpreted the language of the act to exclude homosexuals and the precise terminology
that they interpreted was psychopathic personality. Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic
personality, they must be excluded from the country. Now the question is, which we raised
in the Carl Hill case, how do you determine who is a homosexual? It is our position in gay rights
advocates that the only way to make this determination under the law is through an examination by
a public health service doctor. That doctor must examine the arriving alien and say to
that alien to our gay issue, what is known as a Class A certificate, and then the INS
can exclude the person from the country. Now, the government's position is that a person
is able to decide for themselves whether or not they're gay. And if they say they're gay,
They are gay and can be excluded from the country.
This is the issue.
The U.S. District Court here at the Northern District of
California agreed with pay rights advocates that a doctor's
certificate from the Public Health Service must issue.
The case involved Carl Hill who is a tourist who is here for
pleasure and a journalist, a photographer for a London
newspaper, a London newspaper.
Now the same issue rose again in the case of Richard Longstaff
which is a case that we have just filed a petition for review
in the United States Supreme Court,
the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision.
The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans.
Mr. Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas.
He's been here about 20 years now.
He came here on a valid immigrant visa.
He subsequently opened up two boutiques, clothing stores,
and hairdressing salons.
He employs about 20 citizens of this country.
He pays over $100,000 a year in income taxes.
And our government has said to Richard Longstaff,
you're not good enough to be an American citizen.
Why has our government said that?
Because Richard Longstaff is gay.
And that is the position that the Fifth Circuit Court
of Appeals has upheld.
So what we have now is a clear conflict between two circuits.
I might have skipped over to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
here has affirmed the decision of Carl Hill.
What we did is file a petition to the Supreme Court asking them
to review the Fifth Circuit decision and to resolve the
conflict between the two different courts and appeals.
We feel that there's a good chance that the Supreme Court
will agree to hear the case, and part of the reason is that
there's no constitutional issues.
We're not asking this court, this very conservative Supreme
Court, to create any new constitutional issues of rights
for gay people.
All we're asking them to do is resolve what is essentially an
interagency dispute, and it's more of a question of statutory construction. So our petition
was filed in that case at the end of January. The government's brief is due on Friday, and
the new case clerk at the Supreme Court tells me that the Supreme Court will probably make
a decision in three to four weeks after that. So we could be seeing a decision in that soon.
Now here in the Ninth Circuit, the government filed a petition
for what's known as a rehearing on the bond,
meaning that they wanted the entire court of appeals
for the Ninth Circuit to review that decision.
And the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition.
That came down January 17th.
So what we'll find, too, is that the government will undoubtedly
be asking the Supreme Court to also review the same issue
in the Carl Hill case.
Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I think, to ask for that review is because
as a result of our victory at the lower court level, we filed a petition for attorneys'
fees in the amount of $340,000.
So there's a little incentive for the government to appeal the case.
In addition, on the congressional level, there's been some legislation that is going to be
introduced by Barney Frank from Massachusetts and we helped him draft that legislation which
would change the exclusions so that it would eliminate the sexual deviants and psychopathic
personality exclusions of gay people from the country.
The next area I want to talk to you about is the military.
The military has an absolute policy that gay people cannot serve, and the only exception
to this policy is not really for the status of being gay, but someone who commits a homosexual
sexual act.
If they renounce that act, they say, oh, Christ, was I drunk last night, I didn't know what
I was doing, you know, it was a mistake, it's never going to happen again, please let me
stay in the military, they can stay in.
Other than that, everybody else is out.
Now, the progress we've made in the last few years, at least at the discharge, will be
on your honorable conditions and will be entitled to full benefits.
However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career of the service, this can still be
pretty severe after you've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits in your
particular chosen career and to have the government, in fact, say to you, well, you're not good
enough to fight and die for your country either.
We have a test case pending in the Washington, D.C. circuit,
in court of appeals now, involved a man who was originally
stationed out here at Monterey, the Language Institute.
That's Jim Dronenberg.
He's a specialist in Korean cryptology.
He had been in the service for nine years.
Three months before his discharge,
he had been given a $12,000 relistment bonus.
He had had accommodation after accommodation
after accommodation.
They thought he was an excellent soldier,
until they found out who was gay, they picked him out.
The strategy of bringing the case in the District of Columbia
was that by reputation, the District of Columbia Circuit
Court of Appeals is the most liberal in the country.
And in addition, the issue had been decided here
in the Ninth Circuit some years ago by a case that we had
brought in Lawson, that's known as Beller versus Lindor.
So there was no avenue available for redress here.
And the strategy also would be that if we were able to get
into the D.C. court, then that would resolve the issue for all
soldiers because the issue of jurisdiction and venue revolved
around where was the defendant located.
It was our position that the Department of Defense and the
headquarters of the Department of Navy were located in
Washington, D.C.
And the government fought us tooth and nail on this.
In fact, two-thirds of their brief they argued that the
court didn't have jurisdiction, and essentially for the merits of the case, all they did was
say, well, another court out there in San Francisco decided this issue, and so it's
what Anthony Bump said. Well, we won half that case. We won the jurisdiction issue.
We lost on the merits. Now we're in the court of appeals, and our strategy, we found, backfired
on us, because the odds maybe were a thousand to one of drawing three conservative judges
in which room, three of the most conservative judges you could ever want to have.
One of them started asking questions about did the right to privacy include the right
to have sex with animals?
And you have to start off at this level, you can't be too optimistic about the result.
One of the other judges who was a Reagan appointee to the bench was a former professor of law
at the University of Chicago Law School and a student who did work for Gay Rights Advocates
because a volunteer last summer had this judge
as a professor for constitutional law,
and when this man came to the issue of abortion rights,
he said, I'm Catholic, and I have nine children,
and that's enough said about abortion, let's move on.
So, as you can see, we're not too optimistic
about that case.
There was a really great brief filed
by the American Civil Liberties Union
in that unique as crowd group or friend of the court group.
And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale
that the military uses for excluding gays
and they compared it to the same rationale
that the military used to segregate blacks from the service
to say, look, white men are never gonna sleep
in the same barracks as black men.
White soldiers are never gonna sleep with blacks.
So how can a black maintain control and command respect?
And this is the same kind of thing they say
about gays and lesbians in the service,
that it just isn't going to work out.
And what they're doing is trying to institutionalize
society's prejudice rather than trying to deal
with underlying problems.
So it's a very good, very detailed, brief
and very enlightening book that takes some note of it.
The paradox to what's going on in the military is that
if you're a civilian employee of the military,
there's almost, it's almost impossible to get rid of you.
of you, regardless of what kind of activity you're involved in.
The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has recently
found that a person who is a convicted child molester
still could not be discharged from the Navy,
absent a showing that there was some connection
with his job duties in the Navy,
what we call the nexus between his activity
and his job requirements.
And another area that we find to promise that people who want to make a career out of the
military, they make every effort to get rid of them as soon as they can.
And those who want to get out, somebody who covers after they're in the service that they
realize that their sexual orientation does not mean what they thought it was and they
come to the commanding officer and they say, I'm gay, these people flounder around in the
system often for a year or more before they discharge, even though the regulations are
And how we resolve that problem, I can't really say, but it really is sort of a schizophrenic
kind of attitude, that they just can't make up their mind what they want.
Other problems that we found now, too, is that the military, in some instances, are
trying to prosecute soldiers for asking for a discharge, saying that they enlisted frauds
fraudulent. They knew at the time that they enlisted that they were gay, that their enlistment
therefore was fraudulent and they were trying to have them prosecuted. There's a case up
on appeal on the 10th Circuit Court in Denver, and it's been there for some time, so you
shouldn't see a decision pretty soon in that case. Another thing that we find the military
is doing now is suing people who've gone through ROTC, and apparently they have some kind of
or they subsidized your educational benefits.
And the case that came before us last year,
there was a person who went through medical school,
of course, in the U.S. Army.
And then when he finished, said,
I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint
not because I realize I'm gay.
So the Army said, well, I think we're gonna have to sue you
for $60,000 to reimburse us for the cost of your education.
We were willing to defend this man, but he didn't have the desire to go through several
years of litigation.
It takes a lot of effort to go through that.
And what he did instead was find more bankers.
But in any case, the military picked up the bill.
Or for those of you who are working, I guess we all picked up the bill in a sense.
Which leads me to the next thing that we've done is based on some data we've collected
over the last couple of years, we can make a pretty good estimate that the cost of separating
gay people from the military is at least $20 million a year. That on average the military
separates about 1,800 soldiers a year from the service because of homosexuality. And
that based on a recent RAND Corporation study, cost of training a soldier through basic training
The first 22 weeks is $100,000.
So simple arithmetic will show that that's $18 billion.
And my experience is most of the people
that are being discharged have been around
for a lot more than 22 weeks.
What's the situation with the conscription
where somebody turns 19 and is supposed to go to the post
office, says, I'm gay, how does the system deal with that?
Well, you probably wouldn't necessarily tell the postmaster,
but you would still have to register.
And it wouldn't really become an issue until we were called up.
And at that time, what happens is
that you're given a questionnaire
and asked you to list all of your childhood diseases
and broken bones, and there's a square somewhere
that says how you fit in with homosexual tendencies.
What happens then, though?
If you check the box and say you are so afflicted,
then you will be deferred.
You will not be taken, conducted, in the military.
you cannot be inducted into the military.
If you do not check the box, you could be inducted.
However, if you know that you're gay
and you don't check that box,
you are subject to penalties of as much as five years
in prison and $5,000, if they could subsequently prove
the case against you.
Let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit.
Something that's been in the news just recently was AB1 finally passed both houses and sitting
on Duke's desk waiting for signature.
What most people don't know in this state is that all that bill does is codify a Supreme
court decision which already extends sexual orientation, discrimination, protection to
all employers in the state. The only thing is that not all employees are covered. And
this was the case of gay law students versus specific telephone and telegraph. And I say
it doesn't cover all employees because it only covers those employees who are open or
out on the job. Their employers got to know that they're gay. Because part of what the
Supreme Court of California said in that case was that being out on the job is political
activity. And that in this state, an employer may not discriminate against an employee based
on political activity. Political activity is much broader than partisan politics. It
goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties, includes political causes. Women's
rights, labor union rights, K-Rights. So what the AV-1 does is protect those people who
are not out on their job and it also gives them an administrative remedy by going through
the Fair Employment and Housing Administration rather than having to file a suit directly
in court. Other employment work that we're doing at K-Rights Advocates, one involves
against an act named the Helms Bill in Oklahoma.
The Helms Bill is essentially similar to the Bridge Initiative that was up here in California
a few years back.
While the Bridge Initiative was defeated here in California, it's lost in Oklahoma.
And we filed a suit challenging that bill, and we lost district court level in Oklahoma.
We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver.
We had oral arguments last September,
so we're looking for a decision any time in that case.
The Helms bill, we call, the main issue
was First Amendment freedom of expression.
That was the main cause of action.
It was also we raised due process and equal protection
arguments as well as right to privacy.
In this kind of litigation, I'll tell you,
for some of you who are law students
and don't realize, and the rest of you do not.
We're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat of our pants.
I mean, this is new.
And when we're in the courts, we're making new law.
The gay rights litigation that's going on in this country
has essentially taken place in the last 10 to 15 years.
10 years ago, GRA didn't exist.
And there were no gay legal organizations
around the country.
And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the courts.
and it's not uncommon to find all sorts of oppressive
legislation in the books.
So we don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents.
We have to analogize a lot to the struggles
that were won in the women's movement,
and to the black movement, and other First Amendment
types of cases, the privacy decisions that came out
of the abortion litigation and the contraceptive litigation.
That's where we sort of draw.
Sometimes we make apologies, sometimes we just make up theories.
You have to go in there.
So we feel, at Gay Rights Advocates,
we have a very aggressive litigation posture.
If we don't go into court and file suit,
then we've lost before we've even started.
There is, in a sense, nothing to lose by going into court.
Because in the case of the Helmsville situation,
the bill's on the books.
And if we lose, the bill's still on the books.
So what did we lose?
But at least we go in there and fight, we have a chance of winning.
And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits.
There's educational benefits.
There's consciousness raising.
There's all the press we've got.
In general, there's a lot of good press.
People just cannot believe the situations I've been ascribing to you tonight
about the military and immigration,
these kind of things happening in America today in 1984.
It's just incredible.
And so we feel there's a certain value to bringing lawsuits, win orders.
And it's making a statement, generally, too, that, you know, you've pushed this community
around for just so long, and now we're, you know, it's your game, but we can play it,
too.
And we're going to be there, and we're going to fight, and we're going to win.
You know, maybe we're not going to win all the time, but you're not going to knock us
out of the ring, because you're going to be right back there fighting every time.
That's what getting rights to advocates is all about.
I didn't really follow what you're arguing about regarding
saying you rest your personal time.
I assume that you cannot be ganged with a teacher.
Well, actually, the law is so broad that it could exclude
straight people as well because the language prohibits
homosexual activity and homosexual conduct,
neither of which is defined as engaging in what we would call
homosexual sexual conduct.
It's mere mention, mere discussing of homosexual rights
subject to teacher to a disciplinary hearing of
impossible discharge from their employment.
But the terms in the law are so vague and so general
that it's hard to tell exactly what could be brought
within the purview of the law.
But essentially, it's expressions.
It's talking about and discussing anything
about Homestead Trial.
What was the name of the case of gay law students
versus Pacific telephone attorney?
In regard to that case and AB1, it sounded,
what I heard was that dismissing employees
on those grounds is prohibited.
Wouldn't AB1 also apply to job applicants
and to promotion processes?
And it does specific telephone telegrams.
It does.
All types of employment related discrimination.
Promotions, fringe benefits, the hiring process,
the whole lot of those.
I haven't taken a look at it in a while, but that's a whole other issue, and I think that's
sort of the issue of the 80s, is the rights of gay couples.
We're going to be doing some gay couple litigation.
We did one case already, and we have two pending now,
which I'll go into a little bit.
One that we're going to do in Columbia, Maryland,
which involves the American Automobile Association
and their motor club.
They offer a discount to married couples,
but not to a gay couple, a lesbian couple.
and we're demanding that they extend that same benefit
to gay couples.
The case arose in Columbia, Maryland,
which is situated in Howard County.
Howard County has a very broad anti-discrimination
ordinance that prohibits discrimination
based on sexual orientation, as well as marital status.
It really is a sort of a marital status type discrimination
as opposed to sexual orientation.
However, gay people cannot be legally married
anywhere in the country.
And so it necessarily impacts on the gay community very heavily.
So that's in the administrative process now.
And I think whoever loses that's probably going to appeal.
So we're looking toward a long court battle out there.
We have another case that's in a sort of free adversary position
right now down in southern California in La Jolla,
where there's a gay couple that's been living together for six years.
They have a relationship contract that governs their relationship, and they also are heading
to dispute the AAA, this time with the automobile insurance, and AAA offers apparently a 20%
spousal discount, but this couple of course cannot qualify for that spousal discount.
So we just might have to sue AAA on that issue as well.
There are a number of areas where gay people, because they cannot be lawfully married, have
fewer benefits and employment fringe benefits and taxation and so on, pension plans.
And we don't necessarily, as I said earlier, expect to win all these cases, especially
in the beginning.
This is, we're looking at at least a 10-year program.
But we're going to start raising the consciousness of the insurance industry.
There are already at least two insurance carriers that I'm aware of that offer what they call
domestic partnership or adult living companion that have different euphemisms.
But they offer the plan already.
And I think essentially these discounts are marketing gimmicks.
I don't think there's any sound insurance reasons why they offer them.
And so it's just going to be a matter of breaking it down.
new insurance carriers start offering the program and they find out that it's profitable,
I think we'll find many more start offering it as well.
Some other employment cases we're involved in, one involves a high school guidance counselor
in Mad River, Ohio. Marjorie Rowland came out on her job and she didn't have her contract renewed
because of her sexual orientation.
She won the district court level,
won an order for reinstatement
and a $40,000 judgment for lost wages,
and the school district appealed the case
to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati.
We had oral arguments in that case last June,
so I think we'll be seeing a decision
on that one pretty soon now, too.
In Minnesota, there's a judge there
by the name of Robert Crane Winton,
who's been on the bench for about, excuse me, 19 years.
And according to all his peers,
he's a very able and competent judge,
but he's being recommended for removal
because he would not take a vow of celibacy.
Crane Ritten is gay.
His sexual orientation came to light
when he was arrested and charged
with solicitation for prostitution,
which he subsequently entered a plea to two misdemeanors.
soliciting male prostitutes. Now, what makes the case an interesting one of discrimination
is that two years earlier, a straight judge in Minnesota was arrested and fled out to
the same charges with female prostitutes. He was given a reprimand and a $250 fine. Crane
Winton has been ordered to pay a $46,000 fine and recommended for removal from the bench.
and the straight judge was not asked to take a vial of celibacy.
Now, the vial of celibacy comes from the fact that Minnesota has a sodomy statute on the
coast. Most people think that sodomy statutes prohibit gay people from having sex. Well,
what most people don't understand is that that same statute in virtually every state
that has a sodomy statute prohibits all sexual activity other than between a husband and
life in a missionary position. So even straight people are subject to the same law. In most
states, it's a felony. And I'm telling you, these laws are enforced. In Nevada, a man
was recently given 22 consecutive life terms for committing the abominable crime against
nature. And in that case involved a teenager. And so you can say, well, okay, this is minors,
it's not the same. I can assure you a straight man would have never received the same sentence
In addition, another case I'm just aware of in Nevada,
where there was a scorned lover who called the police
because he walked in on his lover having sex
with another man, and the police came out
and they caught the people, what we say, flagrant delecto,
in bed.
This man was arrested, he was charged with sodomy,
he was given a 20 year sentence, first offense.
So, I'll tell you, these laws, they're in effect,
They're enforced.
And even more than that, there's something
that we are attacking around the country
because there's a great psychological barrier
to obtaining gay rights in this country.
It's sort of the bedrock of discrimination.
How can we give employment protection to criminals?
City councils sit around and debate,
extending civil rights orders to protect people
on the basis of sexual orientation.
How can we give civil rights protection to criminals?
So this is the kind of thing that we have to get rid of in these sodomy laws.
We have participated recently in a national conference of some other gay organizations
and sponsored by the National American Civil Liberties Union in New York last fall where
we are going to put together a strategy attacking the remaining 25 sodomy statutes in this country.
We're going to go after them one by one and knock them off.
We're going to figure out what's the best form.
Do we want to be in the state court?
Do we want to be in the federal court?
What is the correct time?
What is the correct mode for attacking this case?
Is it going to be in the criminal context?
Is it going to be a civil challenge?
And we're going to go after these statutes,
and we're going to get rid of them.
There was a significant victory
in the sodomy challenge litigation last year
in the case of Baker v. Wade,
came out of the U.S. District Court in Dallas, Texas, which ruled that that Sodom Statute
of Texas was unconstitutional. The Amarillo District Attorney decided to appeal that decision,
even though the State Attorney General did not. That case is now before the U.S. Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit of New Orleans, and oral arguments have been scheduled for
the second week in March.
That case, I feel quite certain will also be appealed
to the Supreme Court, regardless of who wins.
Now what happened in that case, it's sort of a new twist,
was that at the Court of Appeals level,
the district attorney said,
we've got to have a sodomy statute on the books
because we need it to control AIDS.
Well, at the time that that sodomy statute was passed,
I assure you nobody had ever even heard of AIDS.
And furthermore, the state and the district attorney
did not litigate the AIDS issue at the trial level.
And so it was our position at the court of appeals level
that it's too late, cannot bring up a new issue
for the first time at the court of appeals level.
That same argument is being made in Sodomy Challenge
to the law in Georgia.
And there, the case is on appeal before the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta.
The other case that's pending now that could have some impact, quite considerable impact
in fact, on solid litigation in the future is a case which is presently before the U.S.
Supreme Court.
This is the Uplinger case which came out of the state of New York.
A couple of years ago, by way of background, the New York Court of Appeals, which is the
the highest court in that state.
Struck down the Sodom Statute in New York.
They said it was unconstitutional.
The state applied for a writ of cert to the US Supreme Court.
They asked the US Supreme Court to review the decision.
The US Supreme Court refused to grant the writ.
So the court action became final.
What we still have left on the books
was a law which made it illegal to ask somebody
to engage in deviant sexual behavior,
what they call voidering for the solicitation
of deviant sexual behavior, which is defined as sonomy.
So when a man named Robert Uplinger was arrested
and charged under that statute,
the end result in the court was,
well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act,
why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act?
And they struck down the solicitation statute also.
This time, the district attorney in Buffalo
appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert
to the U.S. Supreme Court when the U.S. Supreme Court granted it.
And the speculation was that the reason they granted it
was that they changed their mind about the Monopoly case
and they really wanted to review the underlying issues
of the sodomy legislation in New York.
And in fact, that was an argument
that was made in the petition by the DA.
Now, some events happened since that petition was filed.
And when the final brief was filed for the state of New York
for the district attorney of Buffalo,
he did not argue that the Siamese statute
needed to be reconsidered.
And an interesting twist, too, was
that the attorney general of the state of New York, Robert
Abrams, filed an amicus brief supporting
the decision of the New York Court of Appeals
that the law was unconstitutional.
So you had, in effect, the state's attorney general
and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue.
NGRA filed a amicus brief in the Supreme Court
arguing that the petition was improperly granted
and that they had just threw the whole thing
out without deciding it.
And what we're hoping is that they are not going to reach
the underlying issues because the one thing
they're not properly before the court,
it wasn't an issue in the lower court decision.
And secondly, they were not adequately briefed
because as I said, it was not an issue.
Oral arguments have already been presented in that case.
We're expecting a decision on the later this spring.
And depending on what happens in that case,
it could have a significant impact
on your litigation for a good number of years to come.
Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area of security clearances. Security
clearances are necessary for people, many people who work for the government or work
for private industry that do contracts with the government, generally the areas of energy
and defense. And what security clearance means is that the government says that you are okay
to look at classified information and feel that you're not going to divulge this information.
There's different levels of security clearance. Gay people over the years had a great deal
of problem getting security clearance. And what we found is that the government's policy
on this is somewhat inconsistent. They do not have an interagency plan or set of guidelines
or criteria. Each agency decides on its own. And there's an awful lot of discretion that
What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person can get a security clearance.
Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I call them the police agencies, the FBI,
the CIA, the National Security Agency, are hanging in there tough and they will not grant
security clearance to anybody they know is gay.
There's been some recent mitigation against the CIA.
There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia District Court.
It's before Judge Barrington Parker.
And he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment in that case for more than a year now.
There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles, the U.S. District Court down there,
involving John Green, who was an engineer with a company known as TRW.
He's worked for TRWF, I believe, for 13 years and he's never had any problems.
The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information or divulged any information,
but basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay,
and therefore might divulge information.
So that argument breaks down.
The person says, I'm not subject to blackmail, I'm open about my sexuality.
My family knows, my friends know, there's no big deal to me, I don't know why it's a big deal to you,
to you, but to the CIA it's still a big deal and they can't, they just cannot understand
why there might be some kind of, or might not be some kind of problem here. So that
case is pending in the U.S. District Court. The government just yesterday filed its brief,
they filed a motion to dismiss, they said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the
to hear the case based on sovereign immunity.
They said the government did not consent
to be sued in this case.
And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing
on the executive branch of government
by getting involved in this matter.
They said the CIA had absolute discretion
to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not.
So they will be responsible for you following
that on March the 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is briefly some First Amendment cases that we're
involved in is we find that a number of gay community
