newspapers, like here in San Francisco,
we have a Bay Area reporter being censored at a number
of prisons around the country.
Prisoners that want to keep in touch with their gay
communities are not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit probably,
at the Luther Luckett Congressional Correctional
Act Institute in Kentucky, and maybe one here
at the Lompoc Prison, and possibly one down in Texas
as well.
And then last thing that I want to talk about
is the rights of gay students.
Well, I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University,
which is where I first got involved
in the gay political process.
And as a student, I brought a suit against the university
for refusing to allow us to place a banner
on the two official posts, shall we say,
of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on the main thoroughfare.
40,000 cars a day passed through this intersection.
We wanted to put a banner that said, Hey Pride Week.
And the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it's probably because we weren't
adequately prepared, because we found out from some
of our sources post-administration that they had been
warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year
because they probably did some pretty serious trouble.
So the next year, we made an application to put up
the ban on women and women not to have any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has
an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped
lobby for in 1971, last year they allowed that
gay students be kicked out of the fraternity,
simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-iscrimination ordinance,
it's not going to be worth a whole lot,
but it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school in another school
mission called Andrews College, which
is trying to kick out two students because they
alleged they were gay.
There's a private college in Southern Chicago
that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student
who's completed all of his coursework
and said this person is gay
and he doesn't meet the good moral character requirements
of our schools and he can't handle this degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has official,
granted official university recognition
to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space
or any funding or any of those benefits
that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now
involving the rights of students to get recognition
at their campus.
And my last big Bay Rights case before I came
to the West Coast involved a lawsuit
against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
because they were not granted recognition
to the undergraduate and to the law school
gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits
involved with students, as well as many other areas
that are important to them.
We can become complacent during California.
It doesn't have a Sodom statue anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a greater extent may be a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community.
It's sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country,
there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what national gay rights advocates
It's all balance.
It's fighting these legal battles.
I'm not doing this for the country.
Is InterRet's app just taking on any cases involving gay youth
and their rights to their sexuality
if they have not been treated as a concern?
Because that's simply something in California
that is sort of an issue.
And it's very complicated.
Yeah.
There's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically
wait for the people to come to us, which is not much of a
problem.
I get calls every day.
If they don't go by, they don't get at least one call.
So they're concerned about some kind of discrimination
or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
You do talk about this in housing.
I just wanted to point out that this city, Denver,
has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot
live together, and this is often used against gay couples.
It's the status of those in the community that matter.
We haven't had any complaints in a long time
about that kind of problem.
That is a way of, certainly, of discriminating
against gay people without being so forthright as saying,
that we're not going to allow two gays to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation,
I'm not so sure it was necessarily anti-gay,
but it was intended to keep noise down and to protect
sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly had an impact on gay people.
In some areas like that, it's very subtle
with legislation and impact.
In some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.
